subsection.title: Addition and Multiplication
subsection.p: If you add together three or more numbers, such as 2+5+8 it doesn't matter which addition you do first; you will get the same answer either way.

ol.label: a
ol.li: A sum of three or more terms can be added in any order. In the sums below, the parentheses tell us which part of the expression to simplify first. (\blert{2} \amp \blert{+5})+8 \amp \text{and}~~~~~~~~~~2 \amp + (\blert{5+8}) \amp = \blert{7}+8=15 \amp \amp = 2+\blert{13}=15

Similarly, a product of three factors can be multiplied in any order. Thus (\blert{3} \amp \blert{\cdot 2}) \cdot 4 \amp \text{and}~~~~~~~~~~3 \cdot \amp + (\blert{2 \cdot 4}) \amp = \blert{6}\cdot 4=24 \amp \amp = 3 \cdot \blert{8}=24

subsection.p: These two facts illustrate the associative laws for addition and multiplication.

assemblage.title: Associative Law for Addition
assemblage.p: If a, b and c are any numbers, then \blert{(a+b)+c = a+(b+c)}

assemblage.title: Associative Law for Multiplication
assemblage.p: If a, b and c are any numbers, then \blert{(a \cdot b) \cdot c = a \cdot (b \cdot c)}

introduction.p: What about a string of subtractions or a string of divisions, such as 20-8-5~~~~~~~~~~\text{or}~~~~~~~~~~36 \div 6 \div 2 In these calculations, we get different answers, depending on which operations we perform first, as you can see in .

ol.label: a
ol.li: Division: (\blert{36 \div 6}) \div 2 =\blert{6}\div 2=3 ~~~~~~\text{but}~~~~~~ 36 \div(\blert{6 \div 2})=36-\blert(3)=12

assemblage.p: The associative laws do not hold for subtraction or division.

introduction.p: So, if there are no parentheses in the expression, how do we know which operations to perform first?

ol.li: In a string of additions and subtractions, we perform the operations in order from left to right.
Similarly, we perform multiplications and divisions in order from left to right.

solution.p:
Perform the operations in order from left to right.
\blert{20-8}-5=\blert{12}-5=7
\blert{36 \div 6} \div 2 =\blert{6}\div 2=3

statement.p: What do the associative laws tell us?

answer.p: A sum or product of three or more terms can be callculated in any order.

statement.p: Which two operations are not associative?
In what order should we perform a string of additions and subtractions?

answer.p: In order from left to right.

subsection.title: Combined Operations
subsection.p: How should we simplify the expression 4+6 \cdot 2 ?
If we do the addition first, we get (\blert{4+6}) \cdot 2 = \blert{10} \cdot 2 = 20 If we do the multiplication first, we get 4+(\blert{6 \cdot 2}) = 4 + \blert{12} = 48
Which one is correct? In order to avoid confusion, we make the following agreement.

assemblage.p: Always perform multiplications and divisions before additions and subtractions.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: In longer expressions, it can be helpful to group the expression into its terms before beginning. Terms are expressions separated by addition or subtraction symbols. We simplify each term before combining them.

ol.li: In , we do not start by adding 6+2. We must perform multiplications before additions.
We simplify 12 \div 3 \cdot 2 by performing the operations from left to right: \blert{12 \div 3} \cdot 2 = \blert{4} \cdot 2 = 8

introduction.p: What if the addition should come first in a particular calculation? In that case, we use parentheses to enclose the sum, like this: (4+6) \cdot 2

assemblage.p: Perform any operations inside parentheses first.

statement.p: Is it true that multiplications should be performed before divisions? Why or why not?

answer.p: Perform multiplications and divisions in order from left to right.
Perform any operations inside parentheses first.

statement.p: If there are no parentheses, in what order should we perform multiplications and divisions?

answer.p: In order from left to right.

introduction.p: Like parentheses, a fraction bar is a grouping device.

assemblage.p: Expressions that appear above or below a fraction bar should be simplified first.

solution.p: We begin by computing the sums above and below the fraction bar. Then we can reduce the fraction. Thus, \dfrac{24+6}{12+6} = \dfrac{30}{18}=\dfrac{5}{3}

statement.p: Besides parentheses, what other symbol serves as a grouping device?
When adding fractions, which should you do first: reduce each fraction, or find an LCD?

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p: Combining all our guidelines for simplifying expressions, we state the rules for the order of operations.

ol.li: First, perform any operations that appear inside parentheses, or above or below a fraction bar.
Next, perform all multiplications and divisions in order from left to right.
Finally, perform all additions and subtractions in order from left to right.

subsection.title: Algebraic Expressions
subsection.p: The order of operations applies to variables as well as constants. For example, the expression 5+2x tells us to multiply x by 2, then add 5 to the result. Thus, to evaluate the expression for x=\alert{8} for example, we write \text{For }x=\alert{8},~~~~~~~~~~5+2x \amp = 5+2(\alert{8}) \amp \amp \blert{\text{Multiply first.}} \amp = 5+16=21
In the Example below, note how parentheses change the meaning of an expression.

statement.p:
Write algebraic expressions for each of the following phrases. Then evaluate each phrase for x=2 and y=6.
Three times the sum of x and y
The sum of 3x and y

assemblage.title: Good work!
assemblage.p: You've finished the Reading assignment for Section 1.5. Now try the Skills Warm-Up Exercises before the next class meeting.

introduction.p: Perform the operations on fractions as indicated.

li.p: In the Reading assignment, we established the following rules.

ul.li: In a string of additions and subtractions, we perform the operations in order from left to right
Similarly, we perform multiplications and divisions in order from left to right.

assemblage.p: Always perform multiplications and divisions before additions and subtractions.

li.p:
Fraction Bars: Simplify ~~\dfrac{8-2(6-4)}{(8-2)6-4}
Perform operations inside parentheses.
Simplify above the fraction bar — multiplication first.
Simplify below the fraction bar — multiplication first.
Reduce the fraction.
If an expression involves more than one type of grouping symbol (say, both parentheses and brackets), we start with the innermost grouping symbols and work outward.

Follow the steps to simplify ~~6+2\left[3(12-5)-4(7-3)\right]
Subtract inside parentheses. ~~~~6+2\left[3(\blert{12-5})-4(\blert{7-3})\right]
Multiply inside the brackets.
Subtract inside the brackets.
Multiply, then add.

Follow the steps to simplify ~~19+5\left[4(22-19)-\dfrac{12}{2}\right]
Subtract inside parentheses. ~~~~19+5\left[4(\blert{22-19})-\dfrac{12}{2}\right]
Multiply inside the brackets, divide inside the brackets.
Subtract inside the brackets.
Multiply, then add.

activity.title: Algebraic Expressions

li.p:
Choose the correct algebraic expression for each phrase.
6 times the sum of x and 5 6x+5 \qquad \text{or} \qquad 6(x+5)
\dfrac{1}{2} the difference of p and q \dfrac{1}{2}\left(p-q\right) \qquad \text{or} \qquad \dfrac{1}{2}p-q
4 less than the product of 6 and w 6w-4 \qquad \text{or} \qquad 4-6w
2 less than the product of 10 and z \dfrac{10}{z}-2 \qquad \text{or} \qquad 2-\dfrac{10}{z}

activity.p: Use the tables to evaluate each of the following expressions in two steps. (The first one is done for you.) Note especially how the order of operations differs in parts (a) and (b).

activity.title: Using Your Calculator
activity.p: Simplify each expression two ways: by hand, and with a calculator. Follow the order of operations.

ol.label: a
ol.li: By hand
With a calculator

ol.label: a
ol.li: By hand
With a calculator

ol.label: a
ol.li: By hand
With a calculator

warning.p: Most calculators cannot use a fraction bar as a grouping symbol. Consider the expression \dfrac{24}{6-4}, which simplifies to \dfrac{24}{2} or 12. If we enter the expression into a calculator as 24 \div 6 - 4 we get 0, which is not correct. This is because the calculator follows the order of operations and calculates 24 \div 6 first.

activity.p: If we use a calculator to compute \dfrac{24}{6-4}, we must tell the calculator that 6-4 should be computed first. To do this, we use parentheses and enter the expression as 24 \div (6-4) We call this way of writing the expression the in-line form.

assemblage.p: When using a calculator, we must enclose in parentheses any expression that appears above or below a fraction bar.

activity.p: 4. Use a scientific calculator to simplify the expression ~~\dfrac{16.2}{(2.4)(1.5)}.

subsubsection.title: Wrap-Up

introduction.p: In this Lesson we practiced the following skills:

ul.li: Simplifying expressions by following the order of operations
Using a calculator to simplify expressions

subsubsection.p: Questions to answer before the Homework Preview.

ol.li: Give examples to show that the associative laws do not hold for subtraction or division.
Why should we separate an expression into its terms?
True or false: always start simplifying from left to right.
True or false: we should perform multiplications before divisions.
How do we enter expressions with fraction bars into a calculator?

subsection.p: Here are exercises to try before the end of the class meeting.
